title: 107_s1733
content: The Act titled "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" establishes an interoperable law enforcement and intelligence data system with name matching capacity and training. The "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" mandates the development of a unified electronic data system by key government agencies to access relevant information for visa issuance and alien admissibility. The system must have name matching capacity across different databases. The unified electronic data system mandated by the "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" must have the capacity to match names across different databases, be searchable on a linguistically sensitive basis, provide user support, be developed in consultation with private sector firms, utilize commercially available platforms, and be continuously adjusted and improved based on experience and technological advancements. The unified electronic database required by the "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" must be searchable using linguistically sensitive algorithms that account for variations in name formats and transliterations. It should incorporate advanced linguistic, mathematical, statistical, and anthropological research methods. The unified electronic database must incorporate advanced linguistic, mathematical, statistical, and anthropological research methods. Linguistically sensitive algorithms for at least 4 high-priority languages must be developed. Adequate user support includes information on names in different languages. The Act requires the provision of authoritative information on names in different languages and a means for communication with experts. Government officials must submit reports on the implementation progress every 6 months. Intelligence agencies are also required to submit reports. The Director of Central Intelligence must submit reports on the progress of implementing requirements to Congress. Intelligence agencies are required to submit reports on current standards and guidelines within specific timeframes. The Director of Intelligence must issue guidelines within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of the data system. Consultation with various government agencies is required for the development and implementation of the system. The State, Attorney General, Secretary of the Treasury, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, and Director of Central Intelligence must consult with the Director of the Office of Homeland Security, Foreign Terrorist Tracking Task Force, US law enforcement agencies, and the intelligence community. The data system developed under this subsection must adhere to the technology standard established by the USA PATRIOT Act. Access to information in the data system is granted to Foreign Service officers responsible for visa issuance and Federal agents responsible for determinations. Access to information in the data system is limited to Foreign Service officers issuing visas and Federal agents determining admissibility. Procedures are in place to restrict access to intelligence information under certain circumstances.
